CatDescriptText: Earl Branson, stock clerk, Fifth Ward and S.P. Bower, minister, Mt. Pleasant, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 3, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Relative to the race riot in Montgomery, Ala., do you think the Federal Government should wait until a state asks for law enforcement help, or should the power of the United States be used immediately to protect a citizen's life when it is endangered?" Earl Branson's answer reads: "Immediately, to protect the rights of citizens, because the way things are, the people in Alabama really need help." S.P. Bower's answer reads: "From what I read, it seems that if the state asked for Federal help at all, such a request would be a long time coming...Immediate use of Federal power may seem like a sort of invasion of state government, but when human life is at stake, such a situation might call for more drastic action.  If the Federal marshals had to, they might be justified in moving in to an area regardless of whether or not they were asked for.  In Alabama, it appears that the situation is out of hand and people are being injured..."
